results.description: Compute cross-sectional rank of implied minus realized short-term vol to find overpriced options. Applied SUGGESTION1 by combining implied_volatility_mean_10 and historical_volatility_10. SUGGESTION2 not applied (no vector fields). SUGGESTION3 not needed (coverage > 0.6). SUGGESTION4 applied: used high userCount fields where possible. Kept implementation short per KEEP_IN_MINDs. Confidence: 0.82

Same as above but medium horizon to capture term-structure opportunities. Used implied_volatility_mean_60 and historical_volatility_60. SUGGESTIONS: 1 applied; 2 not; 3 not; 4 applied. Kept under operator/datafield limits. Confidence: 0.78

A steep short-to-long implied vol slope signals tactical risk; rank cross-section of call_10 - call_270. S1 used (two fields). S2 not applicable. S3 not needed. S4 applied (high userCount for call_270). Kept concise. Confidence: 0.75

Capture demand for puts by putting weight on put - call implied vol (short horizon). Used implied_volatility_put_30 and implied_volatility_call_30 per S1. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4 considered. Kept implementation minimal. Confidence: 0.77

Compare Parkinson historical vol to close-to-close to detect microstructure-driven dispersion. Used parkinson_volatility_30 and historical_volatility_30. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4: both fields have decent userCounts. Confidence: 0.64

Use implied_volatility_mean_skew_10 to detect skew extremes; cross-sectional zscore to isolate outliers. S1 used single field (skew). S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4: skew fields have lower userCount but still usable. Kept operators minimal. Confidence: 0.60

Momentum in skew: short-term change in implied skew may predict directional moves. Used ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_skew_30, 5) then quantile. S1 used one field (focused). S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4: skew coverage acceptable. Confidence: 0.58

Cross-sectional rank of recent increase in implied vol (call_60) to capture momentum in risk pricing. S1 used ts_delta on implied_volatility_call_60. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.70

High recent realized vol likely reverts; use ts_zscore(historical_volatility_10, 20) cross-sectionally. S1 used one field but time-normalized. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4 considered. Confidence: 0.72

Detect curvature: (call_30 - call_120) - (call_120 - call_270) approximated by subtracting slopes; rank cross-section. S1 applied (three fields condensed to two operator steps). S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used high userCount fields. Confidence: 0.65
Relative elevated put vs call implied vol (put_120 - call_120) signals asymmetric tail demand. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used high-user fields. Confidence: 0.76

Compare realized vol to implied_volatility_mean_90 to detect systematic mispricing across mid-term horizon. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used mean field with high alphaCount. Confidence: 0.74
Cross-sectional zscore of implied_volatility_call_10 to capture abrupt short-term repricing. S1 single field; S2 not; S3 not needed. S4 used high alphaCount field. Confidence: 0.71
Prefer low long-term implied vol (call_1080) as potential carry; rank cross-sectionally. S1 used single field. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4: call_1080 has large userCount. Confidence: 0.55

Slope of put-call difference across horizons: (put_10 - call_10) - (put_270 - call_270) highlights changing demand. S1 used four fields conceptually but implemented as two subtracts. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used high-count fields. Confidence: 0.66

If implied_volatility_mean_30 is extreme vs 120-day mean, it may revert. Use subtract(implied_mean_30, implied_mean_120) and zscore. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.69

Acceleration measured as ts_delta(ts_delta(historical_volatility_20,5),5): double ts_delta approximated by ts_delta(hv20,10). To keep operators low, use ts_delta(historical_volatility_20,10) then quantile. S1 used one field. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.63
Difference between implied_volatility_call_60 and implied_volatility_mean_60 to spot skew in ATM vs mean. S1 used two related fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.62
Compare parkinson_volatility_10 to implied_volatility_mean_10 to find divergences due to high/high-low moves. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 considered. Confidence: 0.61
Rank instruments by ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_90, 10). S1 used one field with time operator. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.68

A high short-term realized vs long-term realized (historical_volatility_10 - historical_volatility_180) may mean transient shocks revert. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.67

High implied_mean_skew relative to call implied vol suggests tail demand not captured by ATM. Used implied_volatility_mean_skew_60 and implied_volatility_call_60. S1 used two fields. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.59

results.idea: Put Implied Vol Momentum vs Realized
results.description: ts_delta(implied_volatility_put_30,5) - ts_delta(historical_volatility_30,5): identify implied rising faster than realized. S1 used two fields and two ts_delta operations collapsed into subtract of deltas. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.73

results.idea: Implied Long-Term Mean vs Short-Term Spike
results.description: High call_720 vs call_10 disparity may identify short-term panic; subtract(call_720, call_10) and rank. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used call_720 userCount. Confidence: 0.56
Compare parkinson_volatility_60 to historical_volatility_60 to detect differences due to intraday ranges. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 fields available. Confidence: 0.60

Short high near-term implied (call_10) and long call_270: subtract(call_10, call_270) then reverse to prefer negative spreads (carry). S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.54

Adjust realized-implied gap by skew: subtract(implied_mean_30, historical_volatility_30) * (1 + implied_volatility_mean_skew_30). Implemented via multiply of two fields. S1 used two fields but multiplication keeps operator count low. S2 not used. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.61

High cross-sectional dispersion in implied_volatility_call_60 (zscore of vector of volatility levels) â€” use zscore to capture outliers. S1 single field. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. S4 considered. Confidence: 0.66
Difference between historical_volatility_60 and historical_volatility_180 to find reversion. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.68
ts_zscore(implied_volatility_put_60, 30) captures instruments exiting extremes. S1 used one field with ts_zscore. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.67
historical_volatility_10 - historical_volatility_90; short-term spikes vs medium-term baseline. S1 two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.62

Divide short implied mean by long implied mean: implied_volatility_mean_20 / implied_volatility_mean_270; extremes indicate term distortions. S1 used two fields and divide operator. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.63
ts_delta(parkinson_volatility_20,5) ranked cross-sectionally to spot rising intraday ranges. S1 used one field. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.59

Subtract implied_volatility_put_90 - implied_volatility_mean_90 to detect put-specific demand beyond ATM mean. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 used high alphaCount fields. Confidence: 0.71
subtract(implied_volatility_call_60, parkinson_volatility_60) to detect mispriced ranges vs ATM. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.60
Cross-sectional quantile of ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_30,3) zscored to avoid outliers. S1 used ts_delta + zscore. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.65
High implied_mean_skew_90 combined with realized gap: multiply(skew_90, subtract(implied_mean_90, historical_volatility_90)). S1 used two fields and multiply. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.57

ts_delta(implied_volatility_put_60,7) - ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_60,7): rising put vol relative to call may signal downside demand. S1 used two fields and two ts_delta then subtract. S2 not applied. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.72
Prefer low implied_volatility_mean_10 relative to cross-section: zscore(implied_volatility_mean_10). S1 single field. S2 not. S3 not needed. S4 applied. Confidence: 0.58

results.idea: Historical Volatility Consistency (std dev across horizons)
results.description: Compare hv30 vs hv120: subtract(historical_volatility_30, historical_volatility_120) to detect inconsistent regimes. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.61

results.idea: Implied Volatility Pair Trade (call_90 vs call_360)
results.description: Call term structure twisting: subtract(implied_volatility_call_90, implied_volatility_call_360) cross-sectionally. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.60

ts_delta(parkinson_volatility_60,10) - ts_delta(historical_volatility_60,10) to find intraday range changes not matched by close-to-close. S1 used two fields with ts_delta. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.58

subtract(implied_volatility_mean_skew_10, implied_volatility_mean_skew_270): shifting skew suggests changing tail demand. S1 used two skew fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.54
Compare ts_zscore(historical_volatility_120, 60) cross-sectionally to spot sustained regime changes. S1 used ts_zscore. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.62

subtract(ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_20,3), ts_delta(implied_volatility_put_20,3)) to detect asymmetry in short-term moves. S1 used two fields and ts_delta. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.63
subtract(implied_volatility_mean_30, implied_volatility_call_30) identifies whether ATM call implied differs from mean. S1 applied. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.59
subtract(parkinson_volatility_10, parkinson_volatility_90) to capture short vs mid-range intraday dispersion. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.56
ts_delta(historical_volatility_120, 20) ranked cross-sectionally for persistent regime change. S1 used one field. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.64
Short lookback delta on call_10: ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_10,1) quantiled to capture immediate repricing. S1 single field. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.57
Difference of (put_60 - call_60) and (put_270 - call_270): subtract spreads to detect term twisting. S1 used four fields within two subtracts. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.60
ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_20, 10) to capture accelerating implied risk. S1 used single field with ts_delta. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.66

ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_skew_30, 7) multiplied by ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_30,7) to capture skew-led implied moves. S1 used two fields and multiply. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.53

results.idea: High Low Range Signal (Parkinson vs call)

reverse(ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_10,3)) quantiled: after large jumps expect partial reversion. S1 used ts_delta and reverse. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.67
divide(parkinson_volatility_90, historical_volatility_90) to assess intraday versus close-to-close behavior. S1 two fields and divide. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.58

divide(subtract(implied_volatility_call_30, implied_volatility_call_90), implied_volatility_call_90) to normalize slope by level. S1 used two fields and operators kept within limits. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.61

Prefer low implied_volatility_mean_720 cross-sectionally for carry; use reverse quantile. S1 single field. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.52

divide(implied_volatility_mean_270_put, implied_volatility_mean_270_call) implemented with existing ids: divide(implied_volatility_put_270, implied_volatility_call_270). S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.70
ts_arg_max(implied_volatility_call_60, 30) cross-sectional: recent peaks indicate elevated risk. S1 single field with ts_arg_max. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.63

subtract(implied_volatility_mean_skew_20, subtract(implied_volatility_call_20, implied_volatility_call_90)) to combine skew and slope info. S1 used up to three fields via nested subtracts but within operator limit. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.55
subtract(parkinson_volatility_120, historical_volatility_120) to detect intraday range-driven regimes. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.59
zscore(implied_volatility_mean_120) cross-sectionally to find mean anomalies. S1 single field. S2 not relevant. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.65

ts_delta(subtract(implied_volatility_put_90, implied_volatility_call_90), 10) ranked cross-sectionally to capture increasing skew. S1 used two fields with ts_delta. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.71
subtract(historical_volatility_360, implied_volatility_mean_360) to find long-term realized deviations. S1 used two fields. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.60
reverse(ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_20, 2)) quantiled to capture expected pullbacks after spikes. S1 used ts_delta and reverse. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.68

subtract(ts_delta(parkinson_volatility_30,7), ts_delta(implied_volatility_mean_30,7)) to detect intraday-driven changes unmatched by implied. S1 used two fields with ts_delta. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.57
divide(implied_volatility_mean_60, implied_volatility_mean_270) to normalize medium vs long mean. S1 used two fields and divide. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.62

ts_arg_max(implied_volatility_mean_30, 60) to find how recently an instrument peaked; rank cross-sectionally. S1 single field. S2 not. S3 not needed. Confidence: 0.60

trade_when(ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_30,2) > 0.05, ts_delta(implied_volatility_call_30,2), NaN) to trade only on significant spikes (example threshold). S1 used ts_delta and trade_when. S2 not. S3 not needed. KEEP_IN_MIND: trade_when used for gating. Confidence: 0.66

results.idea: Implied Volatility Mean Fast Rise Filter
